<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 165, 905, 260]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 301, 308, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 277, 904, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/13  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 303, 904, 317]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 327, 904, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 50 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 728, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 78, 94, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 393, 103]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(y = 2x + \frac{12}{x^2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 918, 157]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the curve at the point \((-2, -1)\). Give your answer in the form \(y = mx + c\). [4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 166, 918, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 510, 90]]<|/det|>
The first two terms of a geometric progression are

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 101, 571, 121]]<|/det|>
\[4\sin^{2}\theta ,\quad 8\sin^{3}\theta ,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 134, 456, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(\theta\) is an angle such that \(0 < \theta < \frac{1}{6}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 164, 918, 202]]<|/det|>
Given that the sum to infinity of the progression is \(\frac{1}{2}\), find the value of \(\theta\). Give your answer in the form \(\sin^{-1}k\), where \(k\) is a rational number. [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 84, 96, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 670, 115]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\int_{1}^{3} \left( \frac{a}{(4x-3)^2} + 2 \right) \mathrm{d}x = 12\), find the value of the constant \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 123, 920, 938]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 81, 92, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 81, 144, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 77, 781, 102]]<|/det|>
Find the first three terms in the expansion of \(\left(2 - \frac{3}{2}x\right)^5\) in ascending powers of \(x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 81, 920, 100]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 112, 917, 511]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 523, 146, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 523, 910, 543]]<|/det|>
Use your answer to part (a), with a suitable value of \(x\), to find an approximation to \(1.985^5\). [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 554, 917, 945]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[826, 945, 907, 963]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Turn over]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[81, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
An arithmetic progression has first term \(a\) and common difference 2. The \(N\)th term is 55 and the sum of the first \(3N\) terms is 5760.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 332, 135]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(N\) and \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 120, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 148, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 81, 96, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 77, 432, 103]]<|/det|>
A curve is such that \(\frac{\mathrm{dy}}{\mathrm{dx}} = 3x^2 + 10x - 8.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 120, 146, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 120, 645, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(x\) for which \(y\) decreases as \(x\) increases.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 415]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 432, 146, 450]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 687, 450]]<|/det|>
It is given that the maximum point of the curve has \(y\) -coordinate 27.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 462, 398, 480]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 462, 920, 481]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 491, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 85, 635, 260]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 276, 918, 330]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a square \(ABCD\) where each side has length \(12\mathrm{cm}\) . Points \(E\) and \(F\) lie on the sides \(BC\) and \(CD\) respectively and are such that \(BE = \frac{1}{3} BC\) and \(DF = \frac{1}{3} DC\) . The arc \(EF\) is part of a circle with centre \(A\) . The shaded region is bounded by the arc \(EF\) and the line segments \(EC\) and \(FC\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 146, 363]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 345, 792, 363]]<|/det|>
Show that the size of angle \(EAF\) is 0.9273 radians, correct to 4 significant figures. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 500, 146, 517]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 500, 470, 517]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 500, 918, 517]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 717, 146, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 717, 428, 734]]<|/det|>
Find the area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 717, 920, 734]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Three points \(P\) , \(Q\) and \(R\) have coordinates \(P(- 13,\) 5\(),\) \(Q(5,\) 1\()\) and \(R(2,\) \(k)\) , where \(k\) is a constant. It is given that the angle \(PRQ\) is a right angle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 146, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 785, 139]]<|/det|>
Show that one of the possible values of \(k\) is 10, and find the other possible value.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 139]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 151, 917, 970]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 732, 92]]<|/det|>
It is now given that \(k = 10\) . A circle passes through the points \(P\) , \(Q\) and \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the circle at \(R\). Give your answer in the form \(ax + by + c = 0\), where \(a\), \(b\) and \(c\) are integers. [5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 148, 917, 952]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 79, 106, 97]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 462, 102]]<|/det|>
A curve \(C\) has equation \(y = \frac{9}{2x - 5} + 2x - 5.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 110, 144, 129]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 110, 539, 129]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the two stationary points.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 110, 920, 129]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 138, 917, 592]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 616, 148, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 613, 670, 647]]<|/det|>
Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d}^2y}{\mathrm{dx}^2}\) and hence determine the nature of each stationary point.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 619, 920, 640]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 650, 917, 932]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 84, 146, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 77, 920, 128]]<|/det|>
The curve \(C\) is transformed to the curve \(C_{1}\) using a translation of \(\binom{-3}{7}\) followed by reflection in the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 140, 180, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 139, 591, 158]]<|/det|>
State the coordinates of the maximum point of \(C_{1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 357, 180, 375]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 351, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of \(C_{1}\) in the form \(y = \frac{a}{bx + c} + dx + e\) , where \(a\) , \(b\) , \(c\) , \(d\) and \(e\) are integers. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 400, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 75, 104, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 75, 750, 96]]<|/det|>
The function f is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(x) = x^{2} + 4ax + a\) for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\), where \(a\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 106, 556, 127]]<|/det|>
The function g is such that \(\mathrm{g}^{-1}(x) = \sqrt[3]{2x - 4}\) for \(x \in \mathbb{R}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 139, 146, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 138, 693, 159]]<|/det|>
Given that the range of f is \(\operatorname {f}(x) \geqslant -33\), find the possible values of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 168, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 557, 90]]<|/det|>
Given instead that \(\mathrm{fg}\mathrm{g}(0) = 96\), find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 917, 945]]<|/det|>
